H0.text: Water would be used less by farmers who plant Bt cotton, because the insect‑toxic genes in the cotton reduce the need for pesticide spraying and therefore the amount of water normally applied for such treatments.

H1.text: Fertilizer is the product that farmers using Bt cotton would most likely use less of because the insect‑killing genes inserted into the cotton reduce pest damage and thereby lower the overall input requirements for crop production.

H2.text: Herbicide is the chemical that farmers who use Bt cotton would most likely use less of, because the cotton contains insecticidal genes from the soil bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis.

H3.text: Insecticide is the product that farmers using Bt cotton would most likely use less of, because the cotton contains genes from the insecticidal bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis.

A4.text: a survey of small Indian farms between 2002 and 2008 concluded Bt cotton adoption has led to higher yields and lower pesticide use, decreasing over time.

A5.text: The increase in insecticide use for the control of these secondary insects was far smaller than the reduction in total insecticide use due to Bt cotton adoption.
